channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: As the small boat floated higher and higher, they decided to ‘just hold on to each other.’
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marvis Long, 96, and her husband, Harry, 97, have lived in their home in North Fort Myers for more than 30 years.

item.title: Russia Plans to Illegally Annex Lands It Invaded, Even as Its Military Falters
item.description: Even though Russia has failed to fully control the four territories it seeks to annex, the Kremlin is preparing a show designed to present a sheen of legitimacy to its illegal takeover.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Casting a ballot during a referendum while an armed Russian serviceman stood guard, in Luhansk, on Tuesday.

item.title: What to Know About Russia’s Annexation of Four Ukrainian Provinces
item.description: The Kremlin is using pageantry and a show of adhering to Russian legal formalities to give the move a veneer of legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A local resident rides past an abandoned Russian tank in Kramatorsk, eastern Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Pentagon Plans to Set Up a New Command to Arm Ukraine, Officials Say
item.description: The mission in Germany would streamline a training and assistance system that the United States and its allies created on the fly after Russia’s invasion, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers heading toward the front line near Kramatorsk, in the country’s east, in May. The Pentagon’s proposal for a new command signals that the United States expects the threat from Russia to persist for many years, current and former senior U.S. officials said.

item.title: Senate Passes Bill to Aid Ukraine and Avert Government Shutdown
item.description: The stopgap spending measure was the final legislative deadline facing the Senate before the midterm elections. It heads to the House next, with a midnight deadline on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: The Senate passed the spending bill after Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, agreed to leave out an energy infrastructure permitting measure.

item.title: Republican-led States Sue to Block Biden’s Student Loan Debt Relief
item.description: The lawsuit accuses President Biden of overstepping his authority in directing the government to cancel as much as $20,000 in student loan debt for millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear

item.title: Mortgage Rates Hit 7%, Housing Prices Expected to Fall
item.description: As the average 30-year mortgage rate eclipses 7 percent, home buyers and sellers are confronting sticker shock.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:description: The added borrowing costs are dragging down the market, said Danielle Hale, the chief economist at Realtor.com: “I can’t tell you how many times I’ve thought, ‘I’m so glad I’m not trying to buy a home right now.’”

item.title: In a Reversal, NYC Tightens Admissions to Some Top Schools
item.description: The city loosened selection criteria during the pandemic, policies some parents protested as unfair and others hoped would reduce racial disparities.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York City school chancellor, David C. Banks, announced that selective admissions were returning to many middle and high schools after some parents rallied for their reinstatement.

item.title: New Infectious Threats Are Coming. The US Probably Won’t Contain Them.
item.description: The coronavirus revealed flaws in the nation’s pandemic plans. The spread of monkeypox shows that the problems remain deeply entrenched.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Flags representing Americans who died of Covid-19, a work by artist Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg, on the National Mall last year.

item.title: China’s ‘Absurd’ Covid Propaganda Stirs Rebellion
item.description: The use of propaganda in the country has been on overdrive in the pandemic, with some Chinese citizens arguing the language has bordered on “nonsense.”
item.dc:creator: Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid testing booth in Beijing last week. In some cases, Chinese citizens are required to get a coronavirus test three times a week.

item.title: Physician Burnout Has Reached Distressing Levels, New Research Finds
item.description: Nearly two-thirds of doctors are experiencing at least one symptom of burnout, a huge increase from before the pandemic. But the situation is not irreparable, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:description: Burnout, in medical literature, is defined by increased emotional exhaustion, a more distant approach to the job and a declining sense of personal accomplishment.

item.title: Coolio, ‘Gangsta’s Paradise’ Rapper, Dies at 59
item.description: From a bookish, asthmatic child to mainstream hitmaker, the West Coast M.C. charted a distinctive path to hip-hop stardom.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and McKenna Oxenden
item.media:description: Coolio in 1995. His “Gangsta’s Paradise” hit No. 1 on Billboard’s Hot 100 chart that year.

item.title: David Geffen Hall, Notoriously Jinxed, Is Reborn Again
item.description: David Geffen Hall, the New York Philharmonic’s Lincoln Center home, is reopening after a $550 million renovation aimed at breaking its acoustic curse — and adding a dash of glamour.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: The new hall features seats surrounding the stage and behind the players.

item.title: Where the Wall of Death Is a Way of Life
item.description: To ride a motorcycle in the carnival motordrome, you need to be an alpha dog with sawdust in your veins. Or at least have a driver’s license.
item.dc:creator: Allie Conti and Desiree Rios

item.title: One of the Hottest Trends in the World of Investing Is a Sham
item.description: Just because a company meets E.S.G. criteria doesn’t mean it’s a good corporate citizen.
item.dc:creator: Hans Taparia

item.title: The Most Important Question About Addiction
item.description: Why do people do drugs?
item.dc:creator: Maia Szalavitz

item.title: Donald Can’t Quit Maggie
item.description: A Times reporter’s new biography of Trump shows the boundlessness of his self-regard.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.category: Confidence Man: The Making of Donald Trump and the Breaking of America (Book)

item.title: The Crisis of Men and Boys
item.description: Men have opportunities, but they’re not taking them.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks

item.title: The Fetterman-Oz Race Is No Piece of Cake
item.description: The Fetterman-Oz race is one of this fall’s big political dramas.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: I Escaped Poverty, but Hunger Still Haunts Me
item.description: Food was scarce when I was growing up, so I ate all I could when I had the chance.
item.dc:creator: Bertrand Cooper

item.title: Dating Is Broken. Is Going Retro the Answer?
item.description: Old-fashioned courtship is having a moment.
item.dc:creator: Michal Leibowitz

item.title: Is the Fed Braking Too Hard?
item.description: It may be raising interest rates too far, too fast.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: What to Know About Ian and Climate Change
item.description: We have the latest on Hurricane Ian, another storm to gather strength with frightening speed.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt, Claire Moses and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tampa, Fla., as Hurricane Ian hit.

item.title: One Man Flees Putin’s Draft
item.description: Kirill, a 24-year-old from the Moscow region, is taking desperate measures to avoid being conscripted to fight in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Will Reid, Michael Benoist, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:description: A crossing station on Monday in Georgia, on the border with Russia. Since the draft was announced, more than 200,000 Russians have fled their country.

item.title: The Run-Up: American Evangelicalism and the Midterm Elections
item.description: A new class of American evangelical leaders is shaking up the Republican Party — and raising the stakes of the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Evelyn Hockstein/For The Washington Post via Getty Images

item.title: Pete Souza’s Obama Book Cuts Obama Out of the Picture
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.category: The West Wing and Beyond: What I Saw Inside the Presidency (Book)

item.title: FDA Approves ALS Treatment Despite Questions About Effectiveness
item.description: The drug is safe, and one trial found it may extend survival and slow paralysis in functions like muscle control and speaking. A larger trial will be completed in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The F.D.A.’s headquarters in Silver Spring, Md. Although the agency’s own reviewers said there wasn’t enough evidence that an experimental medication, AMX0035, works for A.L.S, the F.D.A. approved it, citing the drug’s safety and patients’ desperate need for treatments.

item.title: Two Migrants Shot Along Roadway in Rural Texas
item.description: A local jail warden in Hudspeth County is one of two men arrested in connection with the attack south of El Paso, a law enforcement official said.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman

item.title: Meta Will Freeze Most Hiring, Zuckerberg Tells Employees
item.description: The company’s chief executive had signaled for several months that he wanted to rein in costs as he shifts attention toward the metaverse.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: Meta’s finances have shown signs of slowing for most of the year.

item.title: Dense Breasts and Cancer: What to Know About Katie Couric’s Diagnosis
item.description: Katie Couric, who revealed on Wednesday that she had breast cancer, also said she had dense breasts. Here’s what that means and how it might influence cancer risk.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Torin Halsey/Times Record News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: You should get a mammogram each year starting at age 40 and ask your doctor if you have dense breasts.

item.title: Covid Vaccines Temporarily Affect Periods, New Study Shows
item.description: Experts say there is no indication that vaccines affect fertility. Most people’s periods go back to normal within one cycle.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

item.title: Do Antidepressants Really Work?
item.description: While the drugs are widely used, a new study sheds light on how little is known about their long-term benefits.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Joan Wong; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: What Your Dog’s Behavior Means
item.description: Dogs are “really good at reading our emotions,” says one expert. But we’re not so good at reading theirs.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Nicolas Ortega; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Can You Get Addicted to Melatonin?
item.description: The sleep supplement doesn’t cause physical dependence, but falling asleep without it can be tricky for some people.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: The Kashmiri Chef Foraging on Precarious Soil
item.description: For Prateek Sadhu, gathering native ingredients in the conflict zone where he grew up is the only way of asserting Kashmir’s tenuous place in the world.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan and Anu Kumar

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
